question: Question 2-12/26/2019 Which ONE of the following statement best defines the reactor excess reactivity? The reactor excess reactivity is:

answers.answer: a. a measure of the additional fuel loaded to overcome fission product poisoning.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 6.2

answers.answer: b. a measure of remaining control rod worth when the reactor is exactly critical.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. the combined control rod negative reactivity worth required to keep the reactor shutdown.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 6.2

answers.answer: d. the maximum reactivity by which the reactor can be shutdown with one control rod fully withdrawn.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 6.2

question: Question 4-12/26/2019 Given the thermal neutron flux (Ø) is 1.0 × 10^13 neutrons/cm2/second, and the macroscopic cross-section (Σf) for fission is 0.1 cm-1. The fission rate is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Fission rate = thermal flux (Ø) x macroscopic cross-section. (Σf) = 1.0 x 10^13 x 0.1 cm-1 = 1.0 × 10^12 neutrons/cm^3/second. Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.6.2

Incorrect. Fission rate = thermal flux (Ø) x macroscopic cross-section. (Σf) = 1.0 x 10^13 x 0.1 cm-1 = 1.0 × 10^12 neutrons/cm^3/second. Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.6.2
Correct.
